questions.text:
A 32 year old lady has altered bowel habit. At the gastroenterology clinic, her symptoms are reviewed. She has a 2 year history of bloating and abdominal pains which get better after defecation. Some weeks she is constipated and during others she has diarrhoea.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

IBS is a functional bowel disorder occurring in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities.

Irritable bowel syndrome is a clinical diagnosis characterized by-

  • Abdominal pain relieved by defecation
  • Bloating
  • Alternating bowel habits - constipation, diarrhoea - alone or alternating with each other.

Whipple's disease (Option A):Typically presents with malabsorption, weight loss, arthralgia, and chronic diarrhoea, often with systemic features. It is rare and doesn't cause alternating bowel habits or pain relieved by defecation.

Tropical sprue (Option B):Seen in people with recent travel/residence in tropical regions; causes chronic diarrhoea, nutrient deficiencies, and weight loss. No mention of such travel or malabsorption here.

Celiac disease (Option C):Usually presents with chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, and nutritional deficiencies. While it can cause abdominal pain, pain relieved by defecation and alternating bowel habits are not typical features.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man has a diagnosis of Ulcerative Colitis. He was incidentally found to have positive anti-smooth muscle antibodies by the GP who sent an autoimmune screen. Which is the next recommended test for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A positive anti-smooth muscle antibody test is suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis. Liver function tests may demonstrate elevated levels of bilirubin, AST, and ALT. A liver biopsy may then be warranted.

CT of the abdomen (Option A):Not appropriate as a first-line investigation for autoimmune hepatitis. It's more useful for structural abnormalities or complications, not routine autoimmune liver evaluation.

Colonoscopy (Option B): While important in monitoring Ulcerative Colitis, it's not the next logical step in response to a positive anti-smooth muscle antibody, which suggests a liver-related issue.

Endoscopy (Option C):Useful for evaluating upper GI tract issues, but not indicated here since the concern is hepatocellular, not gastrointestinal.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man had a previous bowel resection for acute abdomen. He continues to have frequent episodes of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Which one of the following is an X-ray change that suggests Ulcerative Colitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a patient with chronic bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain following bowel resection, the lead pipe appearance on X-ray-due to loss of haustral folds-supports a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, which causes continuous colonic inflammation.

Cobblestones (Option A): Suggests Crohn's disease, not ulcerative colitis. It results from deep mucosal ulceration and edema that spares surrounding mucosa.

Skip lesions (Option B): Another hallmark of Crohn's disease, where areas of normal bowel are interspersed with diseased segments. UC has continuous involvement from rectum upwards.

Strictures (Option D): More typical of Crohn's disease, especially with transmural inflammation leading to fibrosis and narrowing. Not a classic X-ray feature of UC.

questions.text:
A 47 year old lady has rectal bleeding during bowel movements for 10 weeks. She has severe lower abdominal pains. Her appetite is poor and she has also lost 7 kg in weight. On examination she has a tender left lower abdomen and loud bowel sounds. Her abdomen is not distended. Rectal examination reveals small streak of blood.
Investigations:
Hb is 10.1g/dl
WBC 13.5 x 10^9/L
Platelets 600 x 10^9/L
Urea 34mg/dl
Creatinine 1 mg/dl
CRP 80 mg/l
A rigid sigmoidoscopy shows inflammatory changes with ulceration and areas of bleeding.
Which of the following treatment options is the best at present?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sigmoidoscopy showed ulceration with areas of bleeding. Hemoglobin is < 10.5 g/dl. This is consistent with-severeulcerative colitis. Treatment includes-IV corticosteroids.
  • If there are mild episodes of colitis, then 5-aminosalicylates such as sulfasalazine can be used.
  • Proctocolectomy is indicated in cases of intractable disease or presence of complications like toxic megacolon, colonic perforation.
  • Antibiotics are indicated following abscess drainage in Crohn's disease.

Amoxicillin and Metronidazole (Option B):Indicated in Crohn's disease, especially with perianal involvement or abscesses. Not routinely used for acute ulcerative colitis flares.

5-aminosalicylate IV (Option C): Used for mild to moderate UC. This patient has severe UC (based on weight loss, anemia, high CRP, sigmoidoscopy findings), requiring systemic corticosteroids.

Proctocolectomy (Option D):Surgical intervention is reserved for refractory cases or complications like perforation or toxic megacolon. This patient is stable and can first be managed medically with IV steroids.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, diarrhoea, and mouth ulcers. Full blood count reveals normocytic normochromic anaemia, inflammatory markers are raised, and biochemical investigation reveals a raised alkaline phosphatase. Barium follow-through shows terminal ileal inflammatory disease. Long-term remission may be maintained by the use of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of Crohn's disease.

  • Remission of Crohn's disease may be achieved by the use of steroids, elemental diet, surgery, or infliximab.
  • Mesalazine may maintain remission if induction has been achieved by surgery and if an 8-week course of metronidazole is administered. It has many side effects.(Option A ruled out)
  • In other scenarios, the most useful drug to maintain long-term remission is azathioprine.
  • Steroids (prednisolone) are only used for induction of remission. They are not appropriate for long-term maintenance therapy.(Option B ruled out)
  • Cyclosporine is used in severe cases of ulcerative colitis refractory to steroid therapy.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with 2 months of non-bloody diarrhoea, colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and 6.5 kg weight loss. She has arthritis and takes diclofenac regularly. On exam, she is pale, afebrile, and has diffuse abdominal tenderness.Labs: Hb 8.5 g/dL, MCV 68 fL, CRP 160 mg/L, negative celiac antibodies.Colonoscopy: Superficial ulcers in the ascending colon. Biopsy: Non-specific inflammation.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient with a history of regular diclofenac use most likely has-NSAID colopathy.
  • NSAID-colopathy can mimic Crohn's and ulcerative colitis.
  • Presenting symptoms and signs include iron-deficiency anaemia and crampy abdominal pain. Endoscopy reveals superficial ulcerations.
  • Symptoms usually resolve with discontinuation of the drugs.

Ulcerative colitis (Option A): Typically begins in the rectum and shows continuous colonic involvement; rectal sparing makes UC unlikely.

Crohn's disease (Option B): Suggestive symptoms, but biopsy lacks hallmark features like granulomas or transmural inflammation.

Celiac disease (Option D): Celiac antibodies are negative; colon involvement with superficial ulcers is not characteristic.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of bloody diarrhoea. She has not had any previous admissions or serious illnesses. On examination, her abdomen is distended and tender on the left side. Rectal examination reveals a small amount of faeces. Blood tests show a Hb 11.0 g/dl WBC 15.6 x 10^9/l. Platelets 450 x 10^9/l. Sodium is 139 mmol/l, potassium is 4.6 mmol/l, urea 43 mg/dl. creatinine 1.2 mg/dl. CRP is 35 mg/l. What is the next best further investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a patient with a history of bloody diarrhoea could be having ulcerative colitis (UC).
  • She now presents with a distended tender abdomen. The imperative management is to exclude a toxic megacolon which is a complication of UC.
  • X ray abdomenhelps in the diagnosis. Colonic dilatation of >6cm and loss of haustrations confirms toxic megacolon.
  • Colonoscopy and sigmoidoscopy should be avoided in suspected cases of toxic megacolon as they can lead to perforation.(Option A and C ruled out)
  • CT of the abdomen (Option D): Can help, but a plain X-ray is quicker and sufficient for assessing megacolon.

questions.text: A 38-year-old presents with a 10-day history of loose stools and mild abdominal discomfort, and recent onset of blood in stool. Ulcerative colitis was suspected by the gastroenterologist. Which one of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Colonoscopyis the investigation of choice to evaluate ulcerative colitis (UC).
  • Colonoscopy in UC shows continous involvementof mucosa with no skip lesions.
  • Features such as loss of haustral pattern, erythema, oedema, granular mucosa, blood, pseudopolyps, erosion, ulceration are seen.

Sigmoidoscopy (Option A): Useful in acute severe colitis or initial evaluation, but full colonoscopy is needed for diagnosis and extent assessment.

Barium enema (Option C): Outdated and risky in active colitis due to risk of perforation.

Radionuclide scintigraphy (Option D): Occasionally used to detect bleeding, not the primary tool for UC diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady presents with a long history of abdominal pain and diarrhoea. She also gives a history of recurrent mouth ulcers. Recently, the pain has become more intense; she has begun to lose weight and has developed fever with night sweats, and she also complains of a rash over her legs. On examinatio,n she is thin; she has clubbing and erythema nodosum. On examination of the abdomen, a firm, tender mass can be palpated in the right iliac fossa. In this patient, which of the following investigations is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical features in this patient point towards a diagnosis of Crohn's disease.
  • However, the features of increased pain, fever, sweats, and a mass suggest the patient may have developed an abscess in the right iliac fossa.
  • Hence, imaging this area with CT scan to detect and treat the collection is the investigation of choice.

Colonoscopy (Option A): Helpful in diagnosing Crohn's disease but contraindicated when an intra-abdominal abscess is suspected due to risk of perforation.
X-ray of the abdomen (Option C): Limited utility here; may show obstruction or perforation but not sensitive for abscess.

Small bowel follow through (Option D): Used for detecting strictures or fistulas in Crohn's, but not appropriate when acute complications like abscess are suspected.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man has 5 5-year history of bloody diarrhoea mixed with mucus. He had lost 2 stones in weight over this time. Flexible sigmoidoscopy showed loss of vascular appearance, erythema, and superficial ulceration consistent with ulcerative colitis. Which one of the following features is associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The extraintestinal manifestations of Inflammatory Bowel Disease include-

  • Ocular - Episcleritis, uveitis
  • Rheumatological - Ankylosing spondylitis, peripheral migratory arthritis
  • Dermatological - Erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis - most common in ulcerative colitis
  • Nephrolithiasis (calcium oxalatestones - most common)- most common in Crohn's disease (CD)

Terminal ileum is the most commonly involved site in CD. Megaloblastic anaemia occurs in CD as vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman has symptoms of lethargy, bloody diarrhoea, and a previous history of DVT in the leg. On examination, the left eye was inflamed and multiple mouth ulcers were noted. Colonoscopy was organized, and this confirmed colitis. She also has vulval ulcers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Recurrent oral ulceration is the most common manifestation and the presenting feature in Behcet's disease.

Diagnosis of Behcet's disease requires - Recurrent oral ulcers plus two of the following four clinical manifestations:

  • Recurrent genital ulcers-cause scarring
  • Skin lesions - Erythema nodosum, pseudofolliculitis, papulopastular or acneiform nodules
  • Eye lesions - Anterior or posterior uveitis, corneal ulceration, conjunctivitis, papillitis.
  • Positive pathergy test

Vasculitis, pustules, and subcutaneous nodules can also occur. Vascular thrombosis occurs in about 10% of patients.

Erythema nodosum (Option A): This is a cutaneous manifestation, not a unifying diagnosis. It does not explain the full systemic picture of oral/genital ulcers, uveitis, and thrombosis.
Ulcerative colitis (Option B): While it can cause bloody diarrhea and some extraintestinal features, vulval ulcers and history of DVT are not characteristic. It rarely causes genital ulcers or vascular complications.
Crohn's disease (Option D): Can cause oral ulcers and colitis, but genital ulcers with scarring and vascular thrombosis are unusual. Also, the combination of symptoms fits Behcet's disease more closely.

choices.text: Change in bowel habit for last two years
More frequent stools last two months

questions.text: A 66-year-old lady presents with symptoms suggestive of irritable bowel syndrome. Which of the following would represent a 'red flag' indicator and prompt further investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The 'red flag' indicators listed in the NICE guidelines as:

  • Unintentional and unintended weight loss
  • Rectal bleeding
  • A family history of bowel or ovarian cancer
  • A change in bowel habit to loose and/or more frequent stools persisting for more than six weeks in a person aged over 60 years.

Also, on clinical examination, the other 'red flag' indicators are:

  • Anaemia
  • Abdominal mass
  • Rectal mass
  • Inflammatory markers for inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has been admitted with severe ulcerative colitis. He has been on high-dose steroids intravenously for three days, but there have been no signs of improvement. The gastroenterology team has decided to commence cyclosporine. Which of the following is a recognized adverse effect of cyclosporine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The side effects of cyclosporine include -

  • Hypertension
  • Nephrotoxicity
  • Gum hypertrophy
  • Hirsutism
  • Convulsions

The indications for cyclosporine use include - Eczema, psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis, IBD.

choices.text: A trial of oral metronidazole for three months.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man has a history of left-sided Crohn's colitis. Though previously treated with steroids and mesalazine, he has had several relapses in the past year. The last relapse, treated with high doses of steroids, was complicated by gastric bleeding.
Investigations show:
Haemoglobin 10.8 g/dL(13.0-18.0)
MCV 76 fL(80-96)
MCH 24 pg(28-32)
White cell count 10 x 10^9/L (4-11 x10^9)
Platelets 400 x 10^9/L (150-400 x10^9)
Serum total protein 70 g/L(61-76)
Serum albumin 3.0 g/L(3.7-4.9)
Serum CRP 30 mg/L(<10)
Abdominal X-ray is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has all the hallmarks of active Crohn's colitis that is failing to settle with firstline medical therapy.

  • The next step is a trial of azathioprine, which is used as a steroid-sparing agent. This is particularly relevant to this patient, as he has had a serious side-effect from previous steroid treatment.
  • Metronidazole is rarely effective in the treatment of active Crohn's colitis.
  • Given that Crohn's disease can recur following surgery, an operation should not be embarked upon without first a trial of the second-line medical therapies such as azathioprine, its metabolite 5-mercaptopurine, or infliximab.

Oral metronidazole (Option A): Metronidazole is mainly used in perianal Crohn's disease or when there's suspicion of bacterial overgrowth, not for inducing remission in colonic disease.
Total colectomy with ileostomy (Option B): Surgery is not first-line in Crohn's colitis due to the risk of disease recurrence at other GI sites. This is reserved for complications like perforation, strictures, or failure of multiple medical therapies.
Oral budesonide (Option C):Budesonide has low systemic absorption and is used for ileocaecal disease, not left-sided colitis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man on no current treatment for his quiescent ulcerative colitis (UC) is found to have an ESR of 95 mm/hr (0-20mm/1st hour).
Investigations show:
Haemoglobin 13.2g/dL (13.0-18.0)
WCC 4.5 x 10^9/L (4-11)
Platelets 160 x 10^9/L (150-400)
Corrected Calcium 8.8 mg/dl
IgG 25g/L(6-13)
IgA 1.8g/L(0.8-3.0)
IgM 1.6g/L(0.4-2.2)
What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is not raised in quiescent UC. Hence there must be another reason in this case.
  • The only abnormal result given is a raised IgG.
  • This suggests that myelomais a possible diagnosis.
  • Plasma immunoelectrophoresis to look for an M band is the most appropriate next investigation.
  • A bone marrow trephine is the definitive investigation, but is traumatic and painful to the patient and so is not the next investigation of choice.(Option A ruled out)

Isotope bone scan (Option B): Bone scans are more useful for metastatic bone disease or fractures, not typically for myeloma which causes lytic lesions not well visualized on isotope scans.
Rectal biopsy (Option D): UC is currently quiescent, and the raised ESR is unexplained by UC. A rectal biopsy would not address the concern for a possible plasma cell dyscrasia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with red crusted lesions around the mouth and finger pulps, three months after having had small bowel resection for Crohn's disease. What is the most likely cause of her skin condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The features of this patient who had bowel resection suggest zinc deficiency.

Zinc deficiency can lead to a condition called acrodermatitis enteropathica , which presents with diarrhea, alopecia, muscle wasting, depression, irritability, and a rash involving the extremities, face (perioral), and perineum. The rash is characterized by vesicular and pustular crusting with scaling and erythema.

Nicotinamide deficiency (Option A):Causes pellagra, which presents with the classic triad of dermatitis (photosensitive), diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis is typically on sun-exposed areas, not perioral or digital crusting.

Thiamine deficiency (Option B): Leads to beriberi (dry or wet) and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, affecting nerves and cognition-not skin.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option C): Causes megaloblastic anemia, glossitis, and neurologic symptoms like paresthesia-not crusted perioral or acral rashes.

questions.text: A 64-year-old lady has a six-month history of abdominal discomfort, bloating, and altered frequency in stools. Her symptoms seem to be worse following a large meal where she also feels nauseous. Clinical examination is normal. She is suspected of fulfilling the criteria for irritable bowel syndrome. Which of the following investigations should be undertaken to exclude other diagnoses?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patients who fulfil the diagnostic criteria for irritable bowel syndrome should be screened for other conditions.

  • Complete blood count to rule out anemia
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein to rule out inflammatory etiology
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies, Tissue transglutaminase (TTG) antibodies to rule out celiac disease. Some patients with IBS-D may have undiagnosed celiac sprue. Because the symptoms of celiac sprue respond to a gluten-free diet, testing for celiac sprue in IBS may prevent years of morbidity and attendant expense

Other tests can be done to rule out any other suspected pathology depending on the presenting symptoms.

Fecal occult blood (Option B):Used to screen for colorectal cancer or GI bleeding, but not indicated in routine workup of IBS unless there are red flags like weight loss, anemia, or rectal bleeding.

Hydrogen breath test (Option C): Used to diagnose lactose intolerance or small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO), but not first-line in a patient meeting IBS criteria unless symptoms point strongly in that direction.

Sigmoidoscopy (Option D):Invasive and reserved for alarm features (e.g. rectal bleeding, weight loss, age >50 with new symptoms). This patient has no red flags.

choices.text: Initiation of an elemental diet risks fetal malnutrition.
Oral mesalazine therapy should be withdrawn.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman had ulcerative colitis (UC) for seven years and was prescribed mesalazine 1.5 g per day. She smokes up to 20 cigarettes per day and is 10 weeks pregnant. She complains of worsening symptoms with six bloody stools per day. Which one of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The effect of pregnancy on ulcerative colitis is variable.
  • In general, the health of a mother with UC is the best predictor of the outcome of the pregnancy. Hence, drug treatment is preferred to leaving active disease untreated.
  • Azathioprineshould not generally be started during pregnancy, but it is only relatively contraindicated. However, azathioprine is concentrated in breastfeeding.
  • In the context of pregnancy, an elemental diet does not risk maternal and/or fetal malnutrition.(Option B ruled out)
  • Oral corticosteroids and mesalazine are not contraindicated in pregnancy. Additional folate supplementation should be given. Topical 5- ASA is also not contraindicated.(Option C and D ruled out)
